intro: Peucedanum cynorhiza, commonly known as wild carrot or bishop's weed, is a biennial or perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It features a taproot that is typically white or yellowish in color and has a distinctive, aromatic scent. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which are characteristic of the Apiaceae family. Its leaves are finely divided and resemble those of parsley, contributing to its ornamental value. The plant is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used traditionally in herbal remedies.
